editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: As it was plaide at Hampton, before the King and Queenes moſt excellent Maieſties.

figure.q: THOV SHALT LABOR TILL THOV RETVRNE TO DVSTE

div.p: Printed at London for Thomas Pauyer, and are to be ſolde at his ſhop, at the entrance into the Exchange 1605.

div.head: The Faire maid of Briſtovv.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: COme Vallen. lets to Sir God-fries houſe,
I know there will be reueling to night
This is his birth day: and he welcoms all,
Fair Anabell his daughter is my loue,
There ſhalt thou ſée the Idoll of my thought,
Faire Briſtows miror and my harts delight.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Frend Challener, I wonder at thy humor,
To dote ſo much ouer this female kind,
That charms thy ſences makes thy eie ſight blind.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: Thou art an enemy to women ſtill,
I prethée what doth beſt agrée with thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: To ſee my hounds, to chaſe the fallow deere,
to ſee my fathon ſtrike the partridge dead.
to heare my horſe Caréere, to drink full healths,
and not liue puling for an nounce of Beauty,

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: I loue to ſée my hounda as well as thée,
My horſe, my fa •• on, and healthes when time ſerues,
But aboue all my miſtris I prefer,
She is the Fewel • that doth heate my bloud,
And therefore Vallenger, for my ſake goe
and ſee, the gallants will be here to night,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Y ſaith you bind me to a mighty taſk
Ile ſee your Lady, and your Ladies maſke,
then prethee peace here will we keepe our ſtand.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.p: For by the Drum the Maſkers are at hand.

div.stage: Enter Sir Godfrey, Vmphrevil, his wife, his daughter, and the Maskers to daunce.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Now gentlemen, your welcome to my houſe,
Good maiſter Challener and your honeſt frend,
So are you all yong gallants euery one,
But we forget our ſelues, boddy of me,
Where be theſe Ladds, what ſhall we haue
No dauncing after dinner? Ho, vp with the tables,
If they haue dined within, and come
yong Ladds now to your dance againe.

div.stage: Here they dance and Vallenger ſpeaks.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Falſe tong that ſpoke ſuch blaſphemy before,
That I diſpraiſed, now doth my ſoule adore.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: How doſt thou like my loue now Vallenger.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O ſhées deuine and I become her thrall.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: Doth Briſtow yéeld her fellow, prethée ſpeake,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A thouſand, I muſt hence or elſe my hart will break.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: What meanes my frend in ſuch a humor goe,
Ile know the cauſe before I leaue him ſo,

div.stage: Exit Challener, and Vallenger. Here the dannce ends.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Gentlemen I thank you all,
Lets in to ſupper the the cheare be ſmall, Exit the Maſkers.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: Vallinger thou art a traitor to thy frend.

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: Not to my frend but alwaies to my foe.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: Why doſt thou loue the faint I do adore.

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: To anger thee I ſweare to loue her more.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: I loued her firſt, when thou didſt loue di • daine.

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: I loue her now, there • ore thy loue is vaine.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: For ſweare to name her el • e thou art my foe.

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: For weare my Anabell, hence dotard go,

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: Prepare thée Vallener it is decréed.
For Anabell, or thou or I muſt bléed?

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: On Sir tis welcome pare not but thruſt home.

stage.hi: Here they fight, vallenger falls downe. And Challener flies away, vallenger cals For helpe, Sir God frey, his wife, and his Daughters, comes forth with lights.

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: Some Gracious Body helpe me I am ſlaine.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Who • e that which cals for help, gods pitty wife,
The Gentleman, lies bléeding héere that came
with maiſter Challen.
I pray Sir peake who hath hurt ye thus.

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: The villen Chalener hath almoſt ſlaine me.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Challener, why I thought you had bin friends.
What was the matter Sir may I know it?

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: About your daughter, and while ſhe was dancing
I prayſed her geſture and her comely grace,
But Vallenger moſt like a liberall villaine,
Did giue her ſcandelus Ignoble termes,
Which I rebuked him for whereupon,
We drew our weapons, I by chaunce being downe,
The coward villaine thus hath wounded me.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: How ſay you wife, did not I ſay ſo much,
He was a Cutter and a ſwaggerer,
He haue my child, no, no, he aymes amiſſe,
Go preſently make ſearch thrughout the Citty,
Where ere you find him carrie him ſtraight to priſon,
Looke to him, come Sir, ſince your hurt
Was about my girle, you ſhall not from
my houſe till you are thorow whole.

gap.desc: 〈1 page inserted from a different book〉
〈1 page inserted from a different book〉

sp.l: And for the motion which you made to me,
Touching my child, I promiſe you truly Sir,
I do not know the man in Briſto,
That I affect more then I do your • elfe,

sp.speaker: Chal
sp.l: Sir I haue • ound it, and I wiſh I may
Make • ati •• action • or your good regard,
And louing care that you haue had o • me,
So plea • e you Sir to know your daughters mind,
Which way her maiden thoughts are moſt inclind,

div.stage: Enter a meſſenger with a letter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: From whom the Letter.

sp.speaker: Meſ.
sp.l: From your • ather Sir,

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Come hether wi • e, daughter a word with you,
I know that once thou dideſt loue Challener,
But he is fled, thou • éeſt a wagering • ellow,
Tell me my girle wilt thou be ruled by me,
And ile prouide a man fit • or thy turne.

sp.speaker: Ana
sp.l: Faith who • oeuer you ſhall thinke méet.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Why thats wel ſed my wench, ther ſpok an angel
Looke yonder what • aiſt thou to yong Vallenger,
He is a man as twere compleat o • waxe,
His ather is an honorable knight,
A Challener, a very ſtock to this,
Loue him my girle, ſay as I ſay, do.

sp.speaker: Ana
sp.l: I neuer heard a • ather labour more,
To win his daughter that was woon be • ore.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Daughter what • ay you to your • ather.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Why wi • e I know what ſhe would • ay already,
She hath loued Challener. And would thinke,
Her • ond in leauing him • o ſoone to chuſe another,
And thinks we would be angry,
If ſhe loued Vallenger, tut v • e thy mind

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Father, I know the • e words are all but ieſts,
Diſpoſe euen as it likes you beſt.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Well • ed my girle then Vallenger is he,
What • ay you Ellen do you not agrée.

sp.speaker: Wem.
sp.l: What liks you two, i • neuer Croſſe,
Mine is the care, but yours is the loſſe.

sp.speaker: God
sp.l: Now maiſter Vallenger, good news a gods name
From whence is that letter Sir may I know,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You may Sir God-Frey, this letter is from my
Father Sir, who to morrow comes to Briſtoe,
And meanes to ſoiorne héere all the winter time.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: He ſhall be welcome, I would my hou • e
Were thought fit for his entertainment,
But on, ſo may I call you now,
And if that you agrée how ſay you Sir.

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: Sir I wiſh it were to night be • ore to morrow,
And by your daughters leaue, ſeale it with this kiſſe.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Wel • ed harts youle neuer be yonger,
Lets in to get all things in readines.

div.stage: Enter Challener, his man and a Gentleman of Briſtow.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: Good maiſter Chambers, your welcome Sir to
London, how farr our frends at Briſto Mal. chambers,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: M. Challener, all well, your frends at Briſto,
Would be glad to ſée you.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: Indéed I dare • weare that I haue ſome friendes
There, but among all, how doth yong Vallenger?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: O the man you hurt.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: Euen hee.

sp.speaker: Cham
sp.l: Excéeding well, he is at Sir God-freys houſe,
And is on thur • day next to be eſpou • ed,
To beutious Anabell the old knights daughter.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Iſt poſible?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Tis as I tell you Sir,
But maiſter Challener I am in • ome haſt,
And pleaſeth you ſoone to come and ſup with me,
Ile tell you then the matter more at larg.

sp.speaker: cha.
sp.l: Faire Anabell married to Vallenger,
The newes doth run like yſe through all my vaines,
Is Anabell married to Vallenger?
A • aithles woman, trothles, and vnkind,
Won with a word o labour, loſt like wind.
O I could rend my fleſh, and teace my haire,
Married to Vallenger, what to my • oe?
By heauen if all my wealth were in the • ea,
And I le • t De • prate, • uckerles, and bare,
It would not halfe • o much haue gauld my hart,
As this • ame newes, this • atall deadlines.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: What chéere you maiſter neuer be • o ſad,
Tut let her go more wenches may be had.

sp.speaker: cha.
sp.l: No none like her, but I will ſtraight from hence,
With my owne per • onage I will di • pence?
I prethée Iaques get me a Docters wéed,
For vnto Briſtow will we with all ſpéed,
There will we • ée the Bride-groome and th • Bride,
Get ſtraight poſt horſes, for this night ile ride,
And preſently get me a Docters tire,
Till I am at Briſtow, each part is one fire.

div.stage: Enter Sentlo, and Harbert, diſguiſed like a Seruingman.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Did Maiſter Herbert then • end you to me.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: How think you, he told me he ſet it in the letter.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Doſt thou know what he hath written here.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Not I, nor I greatly do not care.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Heere he deſires me as ere I tendred him
That I would entertaine thée as my man.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: You may i • you wil, i • you wil not you may chuſe,

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I prethée what is thy name?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Blunt name? Blunt nature?
Héere my • rend doth write,
Tho he be • omwhat ſtoburne in his wordes,
Yet he is of confirmed honeſty,
Well Blunt I entertaine you Sir,
How now, ſwéet loue, whoſe that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Mary • wéet hart tis Sir godfreys man,
That comes to bid vs to his daughters marriage.

sp.speaker: Frog.
sp.l:
I Sir my name is
• rog: good man Frogs ſon
O Frog Hall, that am • ent • rom my maiſter,
To deſire you and the Gentlewoman,
To make a ſtep to walke, or as it were to
Come, or approach, to dinner? This is all Sir.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Do you heare Sir, is this my miſtres.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I Blunt.
Is ſhe not a Whore? ſhe lookes like one?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Peace Sirrha on your li • e.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: What • auſte merchant haue you got there,
Frog breake his pate?

sp.speaker: frog.
sp.l: No by my ſaith, hées like one would • ooner break mine.
Well Frog tell thy Maiſter I will not faile.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Sweet hart ſhall 〈◊〉 go in this gowne?

sp.speaker: sent.
sp.l: The time is to ſhort to make another.
• s not that gowne good inough • or a whore?
By heauen if you maintaine this Ra • call ſlaue,
To abuſe me, kéep him and let me go.
Before an honeſt ſeruant, let him.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Go to, peace ſirha, no more.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: I haue done ſir: Harbeit, whether wilt thou?
Thy loue vnto thy friend makes thée forget
thy ſelfe, therefore no more.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I prethy ſwéet lam content thy ſelfe,
This fellow was ſent me from a ſpeciall friend
Tho he be blunt yet is very honeſt.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: I could be content to loue him well enough,
So he could afford me better words.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Well I wil ſpeake no more what ſhall offend you
Lets goe ſwéet hart, therefore blunt come goe you along,
Sir godfrey ſtaies, therefore we do him wrong,

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Thou wrongeſt thy ſelfe, god ſend thée to amend
And wouldeſt do further wert not for thy friend.

div.stage: Enter Sir godfrey, Sir Euſtace, Mother, and anaball.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.l: Sir Godfrey vmphreuile, & my honord Siſter.
My bony bryde, and this fayre company,
How it glades old Euſtace vallenger
To • ee this good ocaſion of our mirth.
Had my ould true harted Sara lyued,
To haue ſeene the maraige o • her déere ſon
And in ſoe good and worſhip • ull a ſtock,
As ould vmphrevilles: well twas a woman
Few ſuch liue now: you ould fooliſh eies
Will you be watring ſtill.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: ſhe was a wi • e and vertuous gentle woman
The poore will ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: I hope my child will imitate her ſteps,

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.l: Come anaball thou now muſt be my wife,
My huſwife, and my houſe keper, and all,
I know thou haſt bin brod vp for a hu • wife,
Thy huſbands a wild boy I confes.
But let him ſtay and keep thée companye
Or by the holy roode he rooſtes not heer.
But brother, heres an Itallian docter thats commended to vs by eſpeciall friends,
Whom we muſt intertaine with good regard.
Ho, who e with in there?

div.stage: Enter vallenger, Challiner like a Docter, Sentlo, Anabell, Florence.

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: Doo you call Sir?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Fy, Fie, Ned you trifle out the time.

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: Sir I was welcoming this gentleman,
This Gentelwoman, and this docter,
Being ſtrangers here in Briſtow.

sp.speaker: god.
sp.l: Signeor Iulio I vnderſtand your called ſir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: That is my name Sir.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Right reuerent Docter your moſt welcom hether,
My hou e, or what el e, is at your command.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.l: The like ſay I ſir, be bould thereof

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Moſt honored knights whatſoeuer lies in mee,
Commaund my beſt indeuer.

sp.speaker: Euſt
sp.l: Commiſtreſſe Florance you muſt knowe
That your come to Briſtow.
And muſt now help to grace our Bride,

sp.speaker: Flo
sp.l: With all my hart Sir Euſtace at her • eruice

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Sir, maiſter Sentloe is the man I chu e,
To intertaine the bryde, he giues me leaue
To welcome Miſtres Florance.

sp.speaker: god.
sp.l: Come brother you and Ile confer wt M. Docter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What on your wedding day and change,
Is your brides beauty les eſtéemd then mine,
The Bee that Sucks the bitter Hemlock flouers,
When that he comes to taſt the Violet
Doth count his former food as traſh and wéedes
Thou art the Violet the bitter Hemlock ſhée,
I blind be • ore, but now mine eyes doth ſée.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I ouerhard thée, thou baſe Vallenger.
That ſuch an angell ſhould indure the euell,
To linke her • el • e to that in • atiat deuill

sp.speaker: god.
sp.l: Come we diſcourſe to long, wée ſhall haue
Time enough for conference.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: What will you bee ſo Coy,

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Y • aith you men are ſo deceytfull,
That ſhées a • oole will credit what you ſay,

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.l: Why Ned what meaneſt thou

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Sir but one word with Maſter Docter, I com,
Well I will Compa •• e thee whatſoeuer befal.

div.stage: Exit all but vallenger, and The Docter.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Well ſince the bride doth giue me leaue.
Ile bee ſo bould as to haue a Dance.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Docter, a word.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: With me Sir, I with thée.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Men o • thy ſort are ſworne to ſecreſie,
But further me and kéepe my counſell.
In that which I ſhall here impart to thée,
And Ile giue thée a Hundred pounds in gould.

sp.speaker: god.
sp.l: Sir heres my hand, whatſoeuer lies in me,
You ſhall comand my hart and ſecreſie,
It is enough then Docter thus much know,
Tho happely it may ſéeme ſtranng to thée.
That on my marriage day I ſhould tranſgreſſe
So far as now I muſt reueale to thée,
But think tis loue, blind loue that leads me on,
That conquers Gods, and much more mortall men.

sp.speaker: doct.
sp.l: Delay not 〈◊〉 but ſpeake your mind at full.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Then thus in Briefe Anabel is my wife,
But florence is the Miſtris of my hart,
I loue her Docter, Doſt thou conſeaue me now,

sp.speaker: doct.
sp.l: How would you I ſhould help you in her loue,
Why now thou commeſt vnto the very maine.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Thou knoweſt her ſwéet hart Sentlo, hées the let.

sp.speaker: doct.
sp.l: And what way would you haue him remoued.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Why poyſoned man, a little dram will doote.

sp.speaker: doct.
sp.l: Poyſoned Sir, alas you know tis death.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: I if it be knowne but that ſhall neuer be,
Speake honeſt Doctor wilt thou doote for me,

sp.speaker: doct.
sp.l: Sir for your ſake although it touch me néere,
Héers my handile doote.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Cut Docter neuer feare.
Gold will ſalue all, and that thou ſhalt not want.

sp.speaker: doct.
sp.l: Sir Ile ſtrech mine art to do you good,
Tho ventring ſo it coſt my deareſt bloud,

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: thankes gentle Docter goe to florence ſtraife,
With in this houre Ile in the garden waite,
there bring her alone, Sentloe is ſure,
And as for Anabal her thoughtes be pure,
Sentloe once dead, Docter thou knoweſt my mind,
Faith anabell ſhe ſtaies not long be hinde,
Good Docter faile not, I muſt now to dinner,

sp.speaker: doct.
sp.l: Now heauen forgiue thée thy pernitious ſinnes
I poiſon Sen • loe, now the lord forſend.
that ſuch a thought ſhould enter in my breſt,
Bleſſed be the time I tooke a Docters ſhape,
For by this meanes Sentloe his death ſhall ſcape,
And louely Anabell her life ſet frée,
Falſe Vallenger ſhall be deceiu'd by me,
And that deceit is lawfull kind and iuſt,
That doth preuent his murder and his luſt,
And tho I haue faire Anabels loue loſt,
Yet Vallenger ſhall in this • ute be croſt.

sp.speaker: Frog.
sp.l: Come douſe. Now we haue time and place as
They ſay, I prethée v • e me with no delay,
But ſtill ſay, do not • ay you will not haue me,
Now becauſe I am none of your burgers,
But Douce as I am haſtie yet I am not the haſtieſt,
And though I am reſty, Yet I am not lowſie,
And of one that cannot talke much,
So I loue to ſpeake little, for as that
Worthy Philoſopher Hector ſes, the words
Of the wiſe do offend the fooliſh, ſo
Douce in few words and in tedious talke,
Tell me when is this day.

sp.speaker: Douce.
sp.l: What day Frog.

sp.speaker: Frog.
sp.l: What day Frog? doſt thou aſke what day,
why Douce this day of wedlock Douce,
This day of going together Douce,
This day of wearing out ſhéetes and
Throwing downe blanckets Douce.

sp.speaker: Douce.
sp.l: I ſaith Frog you know I haue little,
And for your owne part your as poore as Iob,

sp.speaker: Frog.
sp.l: But not ſo ſcabed I thank God Douſe,
Well, I ſée you regard not the wiſdome
But the wealth, not the man: but the mony,
O Dowſe, Dowſe, much haſt thou to anſwere for.

sp.speaker: Dous.
sp.l: Beſids I think you do not loue me.

sp.speaker: frog.
sp.l: Not loue thee, why I cannot dreſſe my maiſters
Horſes for thinking o • thee: I cannot dream • or
Sleeping o • thee: but for a certainty,
I loue thee indeed, when 〈◊〉 goe to bed
And pluck o • my ſhooes, there you may ſmell
Loue out of me: and then 〈◊〉 ſigh and then I pauſe,
And • ay that Dowce is the onely cau • e.
Well Frog, I haue but ieſted all this while
Y ſaith Frog hadeſt thou bin ruled by me,
Thou hadeſt not bin Froging out of the well
So long: but Frog twas thy fault.

sp.speaker: frog.
sp.l: The more is to come Dowce, then you will
Haue me, we ſhall to this geere?

sp.speaker: Dowce.
sp.l: I ſweet hart, name you the time,
The • ooner the better.

sp.speaker: frog.
sp.l: So ſay I dowſe, for as the old • aying is,
He that hath a good dinner, knowes better the way

To • upper: but
• owſ • , we will be married a ſunday,
And that we will be • poken to be liberall,
Weele giue ten grotes to the poore: with this
Prouiſſo, that if we neede it, weele haue our ten groats agin.
• but afterwards will you not proue vnkind?

sp.speaker: frog.
sp.l: How dowſe vnkind?
When tinkers leaue to drinke good ale,
And Souldiers of their weapons faile,
When pedlers go without there pack,
And water is more deare then ſack,
When Shomakers drinks that is ſmall,
And Lawiers haue no tongues at all,
When Fencers leaue of giuing knocks,
And youngmen hate faire Maidens ſmocks,
When drunkerds ſcorne a copar noſe,
And Botchers nere mende lowſie hoſe,
Or when the cat ſhall hate a mouſ • .
then Frog ſhall proue vnkind to Dowſe,
and ſo ſweet hart lets goe and wed,
and after to dinner and then to bed.

div.stage: Enter the docter and his man.

sp.speaker: doct.
sp.l: Go Sirrha at the back doore,
Bring miſtris Anabel, make haſt away.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: I warrant you Sir. Exit.
Well Vallenger if all things fall out right:
You ſhall haue little cauſe to thanke
The Docter, but héere he comes.

sp.speaker: val,
sp.l: How now Docter, what will Florence come,

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: She will be héere Sir, preſently, and ſée
You can no ſooner ſpeake but ſhe is come.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Go Sirrha, do you tend at doore,
Let none come in vnles I call to you.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: I will, ſtraight fetch Sentloe, to this match,
Are you there Docter, y ſaith ile be euen with you.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Swéet miſtris welcome.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: vallenger now by this light
Thou art the welcomeſt man in Chriſtendome.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Thanks gentle miſtris, but how if Sentlo come.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Hang him I neuer lou'd him in my life,
Only I gull the Raſcall for his money.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: The more villaine vallenger
To leaue his true wife for a common ſtall.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Now by this hand, I wonder vallenger,
What delight thou takeſt in ſuch a wife,
But that ſhe is ſomwhat wiſe, and modeſt,
But to content a gallant ſpirit indéed,
By this light ſhe is a very block to me.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: hang her, I care not for her, our fathers made the match
Now with a diuill what whirle wind blew you hether?
How now minks, what make you heere.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I hard my Vallenger was all alone,
If I offend thee loue, ile ſtraight begone,
yet I had rather ſtay and if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Vallenger, what makes your minion héere,
What are you ieallious huſwife with a pox?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I pray you gentlwoman be not offended,
Pleaſe you my huſband and all ſhall be mended.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Goſip get home, or I ſhall ſet you packing.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: I haue a trick and if it fall out right,
Shall moue her patience ere ſhe part from hence.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: thou art to me, as bodie to the ſoule,
My life is death without thy companie.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: By my troth heere is an excellent rebato.
Would I had ſuch a one.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Likes it thee miſtris?
Heere take it, a worſe will ſerue your furne.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Withall my hart, héere miſtris take • t,
at home I haue a better, pleaſe you to goe
With me ile giue it you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Heeres a wonderfull good faſhiond gown,
Ide ride my horſe twenty milles for ſuch another.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Huſwife, vncaſe, a worſe will ſerue your turne.

sp.speaker: ana.
sp.l: All that I haue ſweet Vallenger is thine,
and what is thine, thou boldly maiſt beſtow,
Giue all I haue, onely reſerue thy ſelfe.
and gentlewoman pitty my eſtate,
think that I am a woman as your ſelfe,
Had you a huſband that you loued ſo deere,
And ſee another rob you of his hart,
Would it not grieue you? Yes I know it will,
But yet I pray, for My ſake vſe him kind,
I am ſure heele deſerue it at your hands,

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Goe, get you hence, or elſe ile ſend you packing.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: I will ſweet loue, and where ſo e • e thou art,
God ſend thee neuer a leſſe louing hart.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: vallenger, your a villaine to vſe me thus.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Sentlo, the villaine I throw back againe,
And will maintaine mine honor with my ſword,
Draw vallenger, one of our deaths is nigh.

div.stage: Here they drawe, Blunt and the Docter comes betweene them.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Go too, put vp vallenger, or ile make you.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Well sentlo another time ſhall • erue for vs.

stage.hi: Exit va • lenger and the Docter.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: I prethée gentle loue be patient.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Out ye Whore come not in my ſight,
For if thou doſt by heauen ile martir thée.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Cauleſt thou me whore, now by this light
Ile haue thée murdred, and if gold can do it.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Gold can do much, but deuill can do more,
Héere is a true paterne, of a common whore.
Miſtris what meanes my maiſter to part in ſuch a rage.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: For • ooth the Gentleman is Iellious,
But I would quickly rid him of that Feuer,
And if thou wouldeſt Blunt but con • ent with me.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: What is if Miſtris, it ſhall goe hard
Shall make me ſtack in what ma • profit you,
Although you ſtill thought that I loued you not.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Now Blunt I ſée it, and will report thy loue,
And for aſigne héere take this purſe of gold,
And now but marke the iſſue of my purpoſe.
Thou Séeſt that Sentloes coine: begins to wear,
And Vallenger is euen now on the ſpur,
And for my ſake will empty all his treaſure,
And what I haue I will impart to thée,
But murder Sentlo, then is Florence frée.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Miſtris if this ſhould be done,
a craſh of your office were not caſt away.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Feare not Blunt we w • ll not ſtick for that.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Then héeres my hand, before the ſun go downe,
Ile do the déede Sentlo ſhall ſhortly die.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: The déed being done come preſently to me,
And we will frollick in his tragedy.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: O Sentlo, wert not for thy friend,
How many dangers hadeſt thou fallen into,
The miſchi • f • now abroach I did foretell,
For by my meanes thy life in ſafety dwelles.

div.stage: Enter sir Godfrey, Euſtice, and the docter, Anabel in her waſtcote.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: O my déere daughter how could he vſe thée thus?

sp.speaker: euſt.
sp.l: My ſon rob thée of thy faire O • naments.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: And for a ſtrumpets loue, O God, O God.

sp.speaker: euſt.
sp.l: Split ſoule a ſunder, that thy ſons ſo vild.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Giue me my child (Sir Euſtice) as ſhe is,
A vertuous maid diſhonored by thy • on.

sp.speaker: euſt.
sp.l: Giue me my • on, that I may puniſh him,
For wronging this • aire ſlower thy worthy child.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Alack good knight, I make my mone to thée,
And thou in true loue canſt but pitty me.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.l: Alas good knight, my griefs ſo iumps with thine,
That as I wéepe • or thée, ſo pitty mine.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Where is my child, where is my Anabell?

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Héer wife, let vs hold hands, and in thrée parts,
Lets ſing around, and ſo wéep out our harts.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: How could the wretch (deare • oule) abu • e thée ſo.

sp.speaker: ana.
sp.l: Call him not wretch, he is wretched but by me.
In mee conſiſts the cau • e of all this wo,
Faire Florence is the miſtris of his hart,
To her I am but as a Counterfit,
Rather I am an ethyop, • oule, deform'd
And therefore hated of my Vallenger.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: O Beautious maid, blemiſh not thy name,
Thou art Heauenly bright, and ſhe as black as hell.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Should any but my Anabell ſay ſo,
Tho age hath ſet his foote vpon my back,
I would maintaine thy Beauty,
Sweare thou wert faire,
Nay more then that, defend it with my ſword.

sp.speaker: euſt.
sp.l: Sir God-frey, • o would I, by heauen I would,
I, wert againſt that fugetiue my ſon,
Fugetiue in forſaking of his wife
To lead the race of an intemprat life.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Héere me but one word, gentle maiſter Docter,
The Lord be with the vertuous Challener where ere he
Be, Sir he ſhould haue had my child,
Good honeſt Gentleman he ſhould,
And I repent me twenty hundred times,
So my goodman forſooth would néeds
Make vp the match with this ſame vnthrift,
And now you ſée how he doth vſe my child, alas.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: This is • ome com • ort in this depth of wo,
Thy vertue is preferd be • ore thy foe,
Why then tell them boldly who thou art,
No be ſtill the Docter, hold thy courſe begun,
There is more a foote, then will in haſt be done.

sp.speaker: euſt.
sp.l: Brother, it ſhall be ſo, he ſhall not haue
A graue roome of my Land.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: He ſpends no goods of mine vpon his trull.

sp.speaker: euſt.
sp.l: Cut off all maintenance, that is the way
To make him ſée his ſin.

sp.speaker: ana.
sp.l: O ſay not ſo, déere father héele repent,
And I ſhall haue a huſband o • new birth.

sp.speaker: god.
sp.l: Girle, thou art to fooliſh, ſo are we to long,
Sufferance in this may grow to further wrong.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: To further wrong indéed, for Vallenger
Hath hired me to poyſon Anabell.

sp.speaker: euſt.
sp.l: What his true harted wife?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Delay is worſe to danger, credit me,
And by that plot Sentlo muſt likewiſe die.

sp.speaker: god.
sp.l: Bleſſed be the houre that euer yu camſt to briſto.

sp.speaker: euſt.
sp.l: A Docter of more honeſty there liues not.

sp.speaker: god.
sp.l: Were he our ſon a thouſand times,
We muſt not let him be a murderer.

sp.speaker: ana.
sp.l: Good Father let it ſuffice you know it,
And may preuent it follow it then no further.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: O thou that rules the lotery of life,
Why ſhould a bad man haue a vertuous wi • e,
Or a bad wife, haue a huſband that is good,
Doſt thou delight in contraryeties,
Then Wherfore do we ſtriue for vertue ſtill,
When we are maiſtred by a greater will,
Come good old man, come myrror of true wiues,
O let my hart with your harts ſimpathiſe,
although I am no kinſman to lament,
In your diſtres i •• gruf • as deeply ſpent.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Docter, brother, whats to be done.

sp.speaker: euſt.
sp.l: Gods me we muſt go apprehend him ſtrait.

sp.speaker: god.
sp.l: There is no dallying in a matter of ſuch wait,
And therefore let vs not be ſlack in this,

sp.speaker: euſt,
sp.l: No, no, brother with your men,
Beſet you Sentloes houſe he may be there,
I and my men, will poſt another way,
No place ſhall be vnſought,
But we will haue him.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Good mother ſtay them
T • is their iourney forth,
May breed ſome miſchiefe,
Therefore call them back againe.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Thou art to fooliſh girle, let them go,
thou ſéeks his loue, that is thy mortall foe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: O thou art framd of conſtancie thy ſelfe,
Challener what a iewell dideſt thou loſſe,
By ſhoing it vnto thy faithles friend,
and how like droſſe doth he account of it,
Come vertuous maiden wipe thoſe cryſtiall eies,
thou weepes for loue of him which loue defies,
Lets in to counſell what may beſt relieue,
Where teares and ſorrow giues men cauſe to grieue.

sp.speaker: va
sp.l: What ſpightfull fortune Vallenger is this,
this villaine Docter hath betraide my truſt,
and to my father all my plots reuealed,
Who flat denies me ſuccor or reliefe,
I dare not I be ſeene within the citty,
For then there is no way but ſtraight to priſon,
Ile call to miſtris Florence I know that ſhe is kind,
to her ile ſhow my griefe and my ſick mind,
Ho, miſtris Florence.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Whoſe there, ſwéet Vallenger iſt thée,
Why doſt thou looke ſo ſad, how faires my deare?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Y ſaith neuer worſe, but all my hopes in thée,

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What is it ſwéet I will not do for thée?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: My Father and my wife knowes all my drift,
And all inraged, threatens to be reuengd,
And will not let me haue no maintenance,
But ſweares to plague me for my wickednes.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is the wind in that doore,
What would you haue me do?

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: To let me liue with thée a little ſpace,
Vntill I haue obtained my Fathers grace,
Then what I haue ſwéet miſtris ſhall be thine.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: And what ſhall I do, beg the while,
No Vallenger your deceaued in me,
think you that ile be priuy to your plotes,
to bring my ſelfe in danger of the Law,
Go to your wife and cheriſh her at home,
I do not like theſe wanton humors I.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: I hope ſweet Florence that you do but ieſt.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Be ſhrow my hart then, do not take it ſo,
Pray leaue my houſe, leaſt your father come.

sp.speaker: va,
sp.l: Giue me houſe-roome Florence but to night,

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Not an houre, ſhall I haue my reputation
Touched for thée, if you linger héere,
Ile ſend for the Officers to diſcharg my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is euen thus, well what remedy:
Lie in the fields wretch, there diſpaire and die.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Pray God that Sentloe be not murdred now,
T • en all my hopes are loſt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How now Blunt what newes?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Sentlo hath drunk his laſt, the déed is done.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Then are we vndone Blunt?

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Why, wherefore.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: The poore deiected Vallenger was héere,
As dry as duſt not left a ſingle doyt,
His father vowes to follow law of him,
Well, would that Sentlo were aliue againe.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Tis done, and therefore now there is no help.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes Blunt, thers help, but marke a womans wit,
Vallenger is but new gone out of doores,
Go follow him, and mark where he lies downe,
And if thou ſéeſt he is inclinde to ſléepe,
Lay Sentloes murdred body hard by him,
Pluck out his ſword, and all be bloudy it,
And then cry murder as if he dyd the déed,
About it Blunt, do not the ſame neglect,
And then we two are frée from all ſuſpect.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Feare not this ſhalbe done effectually.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Then farewell, come to me when tis done,
Meane while ile home, and ſtur not out of doore. Exit.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: The diuell take thée for a filthy whore,
Thou art apt enough in murder, and in luſt,
But like a ſtone in any thing is honeſt,
Well, ere to morrow many thinges will chang,
That dead men ſhould reuiue, it would ſéeme ſtrang,
Now after Vallenger I mean to goe,
To ſée in what place he doth himſelfe beſtow.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I wonder that I am ſo dull and heauy,
My féete doth ſtumble, as I go along,
Mine eies hangs downe, as if I had not ſlept
This twenty daies, pray god it be for good.
Still more and more: well, I muſt néeds lie downe,
And make my pillow of the graſſe and ground.

div.stage: He lies downe and falles a ſleepe, Enter Vallenger.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: How yrkeſome is the day vnto my eies,
My cheeks do bluſh for to behold the ſkies,
Methinks the heauens doth frowne vpon my ſin,
And to repentance bids my hart begin,
the earth do burne my feete with ſcorching fire,
Becauſe that all as hot was my deſire,
So heauen and earth, my practiſe doth confound,
Yet muſt I be beholding to the ground,
My griefe is héer, ſléep doth follow ſorrow,
heere reſt thy wretched carkas till to morrow.

div.stage: Here he lies downe to ſleepe. Enter Blunt.

sp.speaker: Blu
sp.l: This way he went, and here he is laid to ſleepe,
And Sentlo by him, this is excellent:
Now Harbart ſince thou haſt don him all this good,
For once be a littell lauiſh of thy blood.

div.stage: Heere he ſtabs his arme, and blodies Sentloes face, and pluckes out vallingers ſword and blodies it, and laies it by him.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: The Potion I gaue sentloe to drink,
Doth make him ſéeme to all as he were dead,
And yet his time is not come to wake:
Now will I raiſe the wach. Murder, murder.

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: What noiſe is that affrites mine eares
With murder, I laid me downe to ſléepe,
Whats here: My ſword drawne out and blody
And heres a gentleman new murdred,
Some villaine ſurely that hath don this déed,
Hath laid this murdred body here by me,
So by that meanes himſelfe might be thought frée.
If it be ſo, why then moſt hapie I,
that hates to liue, and hath ſuch meanes to dy.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Se heres the murdred body, and here the murdrer,
I chardge you in the kings name
Deliuer vp your weapons: And goe along with vs
With all my hart, ſée ther my weapons are,
And cary me whereſoere you pleaſe

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Goe to priſon with him preſently,
the reſt bring in this murdred body.

stage.hi: Enter Blunt in his owne ſhape.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: God ſaue you ſir, I here it rumored,
a gentleman is ſlaine.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I ſir a proper man, and here he lies.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: O noble ſentloe doſtly ſoe lowe,
Breake hart aſſonder that thy frend is ſlaine.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sir, do you knowe the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Yes ſir, he was my louing friend,
And we at oxford fellow Pupels were,
Then good ſir let me in kindneſſe craue,
That as I allwaies lou'd him in his life,
ſo I may haue his body at his death.
That I may giue him Criſtian burial,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: With all my hart, weel leaue him with you ſir,
and I am ſory fer for your heauines.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: So this goes well, once
Ile be blont again.
For now the times drawes on of his awake.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I neuer ſlept more ſoundly in my life,
But ſtay, how comes my hands ſoe blody,
So is my face, me thinkes, ſtay heres my man.
Why how now blont why ſtares thou ſo vpon me,

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: are you aliue ſir,

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Didſt thou ſet any body to kill me.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Not I ſir but wicked Florance did,
And hadeſt bin ſlaine, had it not bin for me,
Sentloe behould thou Harbert and thy friend,
That thus hath wayted on thée like thy man,
To ſaue thée from a thouſand miſeries,

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I am a maſd, and knowe not what to ſay
O my deare Harbart: O my louing frend.

sp.speaker: Harb.
sp.l: Leaue of imbracments till ſome other time,
The king is com to Briſtow, newly landed,
Come as we goe along Ile tell thée all,
Things wonderfull that yet thou dreamſt not off.

div.stage: Enter king Richard, Leiceſter, and Richmond.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: All haile thou bleſſed boſome of my peace,
Richard findes inſtance of his home returne,
Briſtow, thou hapie rode where firſt Iland,
Doth welcome me now from the holy land.
Send word to London of our ſafe ariuall,
While we awhile in Briſtow heere repoſe vs.

sp.speaker: god.
sp.l: Fame with her braſen trump hath born this tidings hether.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.l: And Briſtow with their Cittizens expreſſe,
Their gladnes by their tryumphe, at your ſafetie.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: And we with you will put theſe triumphs on,
But for this vnlucky accident,
Which makes old Euſtice and Vmphreuil ſad
Which grieues me for the noble gentlemen.

sp.speaker: god.
sp.l: By bleſſed Saint Paule my liedg I cannot brook it
to ſée my child, my aire, my Anabell,
this heere: what a wretch was this?
Now by ſaint Charity if I were iudge,
a halter were the leaſt ſhould hamper him.

sp.speaker: euſt.
sp.l: Tho nature wraſſels with my ſtaied reaſon,
and willes me plead for mercie for my ſon,
yet iuſtice with impartiall wings directs,
My thoughts from pitty, and my words for right,
My liedg to make an entrance to your fame,
Regard Vmphreviles wrong, puniſh my ſon,
I cannot loſe him better then by law,
Nor is he loſt that doth example giue,
Of ſweet amends to ſuch as leudly liue.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Vertue commends thy courſe, and patience his,
In both I pitty, what you both deſire,
If iuſtice could be glaſed with pitties wings,
Call for the priſoner, let vs crowne the time,
With iuſtice, for theſe honorable men.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Haue mercy Richard, mercy in a king,
Is like the péereles Diamond ſet in gold,
he out of enuy and of fury ſpeaks,
I out of loue and paſſion plead for him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What pleaſing aduocate hath pitty raiſ'd,
To plead the priſoners cauſe, himſelfe not there.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: One that doth beare the greateſt griefe of all,
The haples wife of wofull Vallenger.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why thou art wrong'd, therfore ſhouldeſt claime,
Reueng for thée, and iuſtice for thy huſband.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Reuedg for me my Lord, nay that cannot be,
vnles a ſtrang deuiſſion may be had,
For I that am as néerely knit to Vallenger
as bodie to the ſoule, cannot ſuppoſe
an iniury, But think his loſſe,
To be my miſerie and chiefeſt croſſe.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Hath he not ſought thy bloud thou fooliſh girle?

sp.speaker: Ana
sp.l: He ſought no more then I can fréely giue,
and ſacrefiſe to death ſo he may liue.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Did he not keepe a harlot to deſpight thée.

sp.speaker: ana.
sp.l: And if he mend that fault he ſoone may right me.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: He gaue thy ornaments to deck his trull.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: And my conſent did ratefie his guift.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Well he hates thée.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: To try my patience, all that he did or gaue,
Or did contriue conſerneth me,
his act was my allowance.
Now ſince my ſelfe, accuſe not, but excuſe.
Since ſhe that was ſuppoſed to be wronged,
Doth right that wrong, be iuſt and ſet him frée,
For I proteſt I know no iniury.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: She knowes no iniurie, my Lord ſhe lies,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sir God-frey ſince your daughter doth
Remit his fault, methinks you ſhould forgiue him,

sp.speaker: god.
sp.l: Forgiue him, no not I the wretch ſhall neuer boſt,
That he hath braued old God-frey in a iuſt
And honeſt cauſe. Ile touch him I,
I and tuch him to the quick,
No leſſe then for his neck verſe will I touch him,
Docter ſtand foorth and to my prince and péeres,
Say what thou know'ſt of Sentloes bloudy death

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Then this I bow before your Maieſty,
That Vallenger corrupted me by gold,
to poiſon Anabel, and Sentloe to.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Intents are nothing till they come to acts.

sp.speaker: god.
sp.l: and miſtris is not Sentloe dead in act.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Sentloe is dead, my maiſters bloudy death,
ſhould quicken iuſtice in your maieſty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: thou ſhalt haue iuſtice to thy owne content.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: O how I grieue to ſee her briniſh tears,
Water the Crimſon roſes of her cheeks.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Had not my wit preuented this before,
Nor you nor ſhe, had neuer ſorrowed more.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.l: You come my ſon: what ſaid I? No my ſhame:
O let his bloud my liedge redéeme the ſame.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yong Vallenger thou art héere,
Accu • ed for Anabell,
And murdering Sentloe that is dead,
Speak, art thou guilty. I or noe.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: Guilty in both my Lord, and héere for both
Ready to pay the penallty of my life,
Tho in my ſoule and conſcience I am cléere,
Of Sentloes death, yet welcome happie lot,
That ſo ſhall rid my life of that foule ſpot.

sp.speaker: ana.
sp.l: Alas poore ſoule, how griefe and his diſgrace,
Doth make him deſprate, behold his face.
From thence ſpeaks truth, as from an Orackle,
That he is innocent, tho his words accu e him.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Well Vallenger atend thy ſentence.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Pronounce not ſentence yet, right royall king.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: What lawfull ſtay canſt thou impart to vs.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: A ſtay to ſtraighten iuſtice and the truth,
My conſcience charged with this hainous crime,
Makes me con • eſſe tho to my harts true griefe,
That by thinticements of lewd Florence and her guiſts,
I ſhould haue murdred Sentlo, my déere maiſter,
I therefore think that through her wickednes
She is the cauſe of all theſe villainies.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Poſt officers, and fetch her to our preſence.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: A weake delay to hinder my ſtrong faith.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: I euer thought that Harlot would be one.
Sée how that bold • ace ieats it like a bride.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Health to the king, good fortune to the péeres.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: A boulder quean ther liude not this many years.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My pearcing iudgment, through the brittle glaſſe,
Of that fraile beauty, doth deſerne her looſenes,
Lady ſtand forth.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I entertaine that name moſt royall king,
And boldly come héere to cléere my ſelfe,
Of any thing that ſhall be laid againſt me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You are héere acuſed as acceſſarie,
Vnto Sentloes death, ſpeake are you guilty I or no.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Doth this diſgraced ſon of that proud man,
Charg me with theſe ſurmiſes before the king.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Thou haſt not murdred him, but my renowne,
His death, this hand my death of fame doth wound.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Thus luſt makes yong mens miſſery her law.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Who then dares tuch my reputation?

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.l: Looke there on thy accuſer, that is he.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: This coriſh lumpe of fleſh, this ſhaghaird ſlaue,

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.l: Aplie thy ſpéech proud woman to the place,
Speake reuerently in preſence of the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lady we ſtand not vpon words,
But one the proffe, and eſtimate of right,
Sirtha, ſtand forth: and fréely ſpeake the truth.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: The wretch my Lord that neuer did offend,
Fears not to die, I charge thée Florence
Of my maiſters death: Moreouer, I charg thée
That with this purſe of maſſie gold
Thou didſt bribe me,
To murder Sentloe, Sentlo that is dead.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: I bribe thée, with what falſe-hood doſt thou vrge me.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Let Vallenger be aſked what purſe this is,
Looke on it Ladies, marke it, for you know it.

sp.speaker: Ana
sp.l: This purſe was mine.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: This purſe I gaue to Florence.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then with this purſe, we holdly may conclude
that ſhe did bribe Blunt to murder Sentloe.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.l: Looke on her face my Lord, her couller changeth.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Am I diſcride, ſhall yonder coriſh ſlaue,
By blabing tongue bring me to infamy,
No tho I aſſure my death, ile further his.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Your anſwere Florence, what debate you there▪

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: My anſwere ſhall be reſolute and true,
Worthy the vallor of a womans mind,
To bad for thée, thou lumpe of infamy.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.l: Nothing but badnes is from bad deriued.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Moſt mighty king, I fréely do confes,
That curſed Blunt conſented to murder Sentloe,
This is the truth of all, liue I or die.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Lewd is her life my Lord, and loſe her toong.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Well take them aſide,
In Florence I obſerue her impudence,
In Vallenger diſpaire, in Blunt remorce,
In theſe thrée laſt front terror,
Call them agen, attend your ſentence all,
Firſt Vallenger, thou ſoughteſt to poiſon Anabell thy wiſe,
Since by aparent proffe Sentlo is ſlaine,
Our ſentence is reſpectiue for thy good,
A noble death: the loſſe of thy lewd head,
Blunt, and this honeſt Florence,
Both for committing and concealing murder,
Muſt one the gallowes die, this is our ſencence.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: No act is proued in me right royall king.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Her words approue thy act, thy act her will.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: My faults is in conſealment, not attempt.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: His fault is murder, hang vs all my Lord.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.l: Harbart for all your kindnes to my ſon,
Ile ſée you ſhortly caper in a cord.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Sée then you hang vs cloſely, then my Lord
To kis in death, as we haue kiſt in life.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Boſt not thy ſhame, nor ſhame thou womanhood,

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Alack good god, how holy is ſhe growen,
ſhe loues the fleſh, yet dares not make it knowne.

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: I do imbrace the law, as plea • ed to die,
Father forgiue the follies of my youth,
Vmphrevill, let me beare to heauen
Vpon the wings o • my vnfained repentance,
My ſorrow héere indented in my tears,
And thou indued wonder of thy • exe,
Forgiue the wrongs that I haue done to thee,
That I may go with peace vnto my death.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Away with them,
To morrow • ée execution be per • ormd,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: O mercy Richard, ſhow ſome mercy,
Will Vallenger in ſilence loſſe his ſon,
And harder then the Penerian rockes,
Neuer be perſt,
Although the Father will not, Richmond plead:
And if that Richmond dare not, Lieſtor ſpeak,
O ſée the time fléets hence with Swolloes wings,
Time runs: O Gratious king be mercifull.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Lady I cannot breake the limites of the law,
A wilfull murder muſt be paid with death,
Yet bring me a man that willingly will yéeld
Sufferance of death, to ſaue yong Vallenger,
And he ſhall liue, elſe hope no further grace:
Atend our further pleaſurs at the court.

sp.speaker: ana.
sp.l: This is ſome comfort, happie Anabell,
Now ſhow thy ready and thy womans wit.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: How ſhall he liue in one will die for him,
Well Vallenger, i • thou haue ſuch a friend:
Thou art happie, but I mean to ſée the end.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Thus like a frier I haue diſguiſed my ſelfe,
To ſée my déere friend, that hath ſaued my life,
And that ſame ſtrumpet that
Would haue cauſed my death.
A harlots loue, is like a chimney ſmoke,
Quiuering in the aire betwéene two blaſts of winde,
Borne heere and there by either of the ſame,
And properly to none of both inclind,
Hate, and diſpaire, is painted in their eies,
Deceit, and treaſon, in their boſſome lies:
Their promiſes, are made of brittle glaſſe,
Ground like a phillip, to the fineſt duſt,
Their thoughts like ſtreaming riuers ſwiftly paſſe,
Their words are oyle, and yet they geather ruſt,
True are they neuer found, but in vntruth:
Conſtant in nought, but in vnconſtancie:
Deuouring cankars of mans liberty,
But ſtay: I am at the priſon gate,
Where are you kéeper, let me ſpeake with you?

sp.speaker: keep.
sp.l: Who knocks there?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: A fryer come to confeſſe your priſoners.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Stay ile bring them to you preſently.

div.stage: Enter Vallenger, Florence, and Blunt. and the keeper.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Health to this place: ſir, let me ſpeake with you.
Do you not ſorrow inward at your hart,
For your looſe life you haue ſo wanton ſpent.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes: from my hart Sir, and do thinke it long,
That this vild life of mine doth breath ſo long.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Do not diſpaire, although your death be nie,
Heauen looke vpon you with a Gracious eie.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Now gentlewoman: let me ſpeake with you,
Now good fellow, what wouldſt thou haue with me?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: To confes truly your offences paſt.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Well: ſhall I confes one thing truly to thée,

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: One thing, and euery thing.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Why then I confes truely that before
This time neuer confeſt any thing truely,
But in briefe father ile tell thée,
All that I couſeaned, I de • rauded:
Thoſe I haue ſlandered, I haue defamed,
Whom I hated, I loued not:
And this hath bin the manner of my life.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Are you not ſorry for that you haue done.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: No by my troth, nere a whit at all.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I hope your mind will chang be • ore you die.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Perhaps you know ſo much: truſt me, not I.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: God turn your hart: frend let me ſpeak with you,
The time draws néere of execution,
What is it méete I goe along with you?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I gentle Sentloe, and thy ſel • e ſhall ſée,
The deference twixt luſt, and chaſtity

sp.speaker: Meſ.
sp.l: You muſt bring the priſoners away,
the king and péeres are already ſet.

sp.speaker: keep.
sp.l: Say we make all the ſpéed we may.

sp.speaker: flo.
sp.l: Come noble harts, lets fearles march away,
A little hanging will diſpatch vs all.

stage.hi:
Enter the king, Richmond, Lieſter Sir
Euſtice, Sir Godfrey, to the execution.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Sir Godfrey, and Sir Euſtice vallenger,
Your Siluer haires ſhoulde teach you patience.

sp.speaker: god.
sp.l: My ledge, God be my record I do not repine,
Alack good knight, thou wéeps in vaine,
But now there is no helpe.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.l: I, I, my Soueraine iuſtice on my ſon,
He hath deſerued death, and let him haue it.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Sir godfrey, hath your daughter yet
Found out a man will die for Vallenger,
Such was our promiſe in regard of her,
And ſince our word is paſt, we graunt it him.

sp.speaker: god.
sp.l: No, no, my Soueraine, I haue hard,
A man vrged by neſ • eſity to lead his frend,
Or to redéeme his perſon with his owne,
But to find one will die for a frend,
This age we liue in doth not now a • ord.

div.stage: Enter the officers with the priſoners.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Diſpoſe yong Vallenger the firſt to death,
That done, ſend hence the other to their ſentence domd

sp.speaker: va.
sp.l: The lateſt period o • this life of mine,
Firſt let me do my deuty to my prince.
Next vnto you, to much by me offended,
Mount thou my ſoule into the throwne o grace,
I my o • fence might be • orgiuen on earth,
I would aſke pardon of my dread king.
My parents, and my wife,
That muſt forgiue me,
But my hatefull life
Hath ſo be bloted and beſmered my fault,
That when I come to aſk the laſt forgiuenes,
They will not liſt my ſute,
Nor yet regard it.

div.stage: Enter at one doore, Anabell diſguiſed like a man, and at another Challener.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Stay: héere is one will die for vallenger.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: Nay héere is one will die for Vallenger.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Be blínd mine eies, O vertuous Challener.
Come to redéeme his enemy from death.

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: O Challener, by the déep wrongs that I haue done to thee,
O hide thy face, thy lookes are far more keene,
Then is the axe, muſt ſtrike the fatall ſtroke:
For thee ſweet youth, thou canſt aledge no reaſon
Why thou ſhouldſt die for me,
Be iuſt O king.
No torment worſe, then fruitles lingering.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Diſpatch them executioner: diſpatch.

sp.speaker: ana.
sp.l: Stay executioner: do me iuſtice king,
thy word is paſt that vallenger ſhall liue,
If any one will looſe his life for him,
And that will I: ile dy for vallenger,

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: Nay heere is one, that for the loue he beares,
to Anabell, but not to him, will die for vallenger.

sp.speaker: ana.
sp.l: My plea was entred firſt, my claime muſt ſtand.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Tell me but what thou art, raſh yongman,
that dares enter into this place before me:
humannity doth teach thee thou euer ſhouldſt
Giue place vnto thine elders, in all aſaies,
how rude then and vnmannerly art thou,
To forget this common courteſie,
that parents teach their children euery houre.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Sir, in humanity I muſt confeſſe,
So much as you aledge but not in death.
the graue is as the publick theater,
the roome being taken vp, by them firſt enter,
the ſecond ſort muſt ſit but as they come.
Beſids you ſay you die for anabell,
She nere deſerued death: therfore giue your ple •
to him that hath true title for the ſame.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Thats not by thée fond girle,
Knéele Euſtice, knéele, do not acept
Againſt her folly, do not good my ledge.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why you amaze me, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Why my ledge, this is my child, my anabell?
Came in this diſguyſe,
to ſaue his life, that was the ſpoile of hers,
Now aforegod girle thou art much to blame.
What is that other?

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: My Lord, this is vertuous Challener,
Come to redéeme his enemy from death.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: a conflickt of exceeding conſequence,
and much renownes that worthy gentleman,
tho let me tell you we are much diſpleaſd,
that anabell ſhould baffel thus our lawes,
We aſked a man, and ſhe a woman to delude vs.
therefore we are content her huſband haue his life,
But ſhe ſhall lay her head vpon the block,
and ſhe ſhall haue no executioner,
But vallenger him ſelfe, ſhall ſtrike it off:
this is our ſentence, and we will not chang.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: pray god thou doſt not king, for I accept it.
Come Vallenger, that happy hand of thine,
Shall aue thy li e and make an end o • mine.

sp.speaker: val.
sp.l: To ſtrike the ſtroke, to murder Anabell,
Firſt let my ſoule ſinck to the pit o • hell.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: A man the executioner of his wi e,
Is ſo vnhumaine that a mortall eie
Would euen be bloudſhed to behold the ſame,
There ore dread king let me die or both,
But to de • end • o ſcandelus an act:
And as • or thée, I hate thée Vallenger,
And could be well content withall my hart,
To be thy deathes man • or thou hateſt me,
Beſids, yet Valenger conſider this,
Hauing a wi • e • o faire as Anabell,
Beloued of me thy foe, and • o intierly,
That I do offer vp my li e for hers,
Should mercy pardon now what law doth threaten,
Thou muſt immagin if that we too liue,
I ſtill ſhould go about to murder thée,
To inioy thy wi • e, whom I • o much do loue,
there • ore beg of the king that onely I may die,
to ſaue her honor, and thy in • amie.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Hark you huſwi • e, do you heare all this:
Doth not your hart melt at this amis.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Melt Blunt yes, and doth wéepe briniſh tears,
to ſée what • ames them, and doth me confound,
Héere is a glaſſe for ſuch as liues by luſt,
See what tis to be honeſt, what tis to be iuſt,

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Why this is wel: now Soueraine hear me ſpeak,
I • he that is • uppoſed ſlaine doth liue,
Then • riendly may we reconſile the • e iars,

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Our law doeth light on none, but guilty crimes:
And that it puniſheth as iuſtice willes.

sp.speaker: Blu.
sp.l: Why then vouchſa • e all in this princely preſence,
This gentleman and I brought all to paſſe,
He in a Docters ſhape, hath ſaued the life
O • my frend Sentloe, and o Anabell,
I in like ſort haue aued Vallenger,
And Sentloe which by me ſhould haue bin ſlaine,
I ſaued him by an honeſt policie.
And now aliue preſent him to your ſight,
To make a pleaſing end o • theſe ſad ſightes.
sp.stage: Heere Sentloe putteth off his whod and kneeles downe.
sp.l: This breaths new life into my hated hart.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sweet beautious lettes the cauſer of my ſmart,
Forget in me, what I haue done amiſſe,
And ſeale my pardon with one balmy kiſſe
My ſoule repents her lewd impyetie.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: My blouds déere ſolace, and my beſt content,
My onely déere eſteemed Vallenger,
Not all the world being turned into pleaſure,
Could giue my ſoule ſuch ſwéet contented treaſure,
Thou art more deere, more pleaſing to my mind,
then at the firſt: before thou proueſt vnkind,
tis inſident for yong men to offend,
And wiues muſt ſtay their leaſures to amend.

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: This kind contryſſion of yong vallenger,
More ioyes my hart, then reſt to trauelers,
Liue long together, and may neuer fate,
this new ioynd league of marriage ſeperate.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: The like ſay I, to thee that now hath tryed,
A friends firme faith, that nothing can deuide.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: the which I will indeuer to deſerue,
And not ſo much as once in thought to ſwerue.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Since all things ſorteth to this happines,
And pining care, is turned to ioy • ull mirth,
I will be partner in your meryment,
Away with that ſame tradgike monument,
For that ſame Florence there, becau • e we ſée,
ſhe • orrowes ſomthing for her follies paſt,
Let her be had among the Conuertines.
And as her faults ſhall vaniſh or elſe ſtay,
Let her be v • ed accordingly. Away with her,
Glad parents, and glad frends,
In Briſtow here a while our ſelues will ſtay,
And ſpend ſome ſportfull houres to crowne your ioy
After ſo many troubles, and tyerd annoy.
